* The etymology of "lo" (the definite article) is uncertain, but it is thought to be derived from the Latin demonstrative pronoun "ille". * The etymology of "duce" is from the Latin word "dux", meaning "leader". * The etymology of "mio" is from the Latin possessive adjective "meus", meaning "mine". * The etymology of "dire" is from the Latin verb "dicere", meaning "to say". * The etymology of "per" is from the Latin preposition "per", meaning "through" or "by means of". * The etymology of "questo" is from the Latin demonstrative pronoun "eccum+istum", meaning "this". * The etymology of "luogo" is from the Latin noun "locus", meaning "place". * The etymology of "si" is from the Latin reflexive pronoun "se", meaning "himself", "herself", or "itself". * The etymology of "volere" is from the Latin verb "velle", meaning "to want". * The etymology of "tenere" is from the Latin verb "tenere", meaning "to hold". * The etymology of "a" is from the Latin preposition "ad", meaning "to" or "at". * The etymology of "occhio" is from the Latin noun "oculus", meaning "eye". * The etymology of "stretto" is from the Latin adjective "strictus", meaning "narrow". * The etymology of "il" is from the Latin demonstrative pronoun "ille", meaning "that". * The etymology of "freno" is from the Germanic verb *bregdan*, meaning "to restrain". * The etymology of "però" is from the Latin phrase "per hoc", meaning "for this reason". * The etymology of "che" is from the Latin relative pronoun "quod", meaning "that" or "which". * The etymology of "errare" is from the Latin verb "errare", meaning "to wander". * The etymology of "potere" is from the Latin verb "posse", meaning "to be able". * The etymology of "poco" is from the Latin adjective "paucus", meaning "few".
